sub_title: Doctoral Candidate, Building Services Group at Technische Universiteit Eindhoven
summary: I am a researcher in the field of Built Environment. In the past, I have worked in the field of building energy services and gained experience on whole building energy performance analysis, energy benchmarking, Solar PV system design & costing and SaaS product development. I also have research experience on topics such as Thermal Energy Storage using Phase Change Materials and Cost-Benefit Analysis of Nul op de Meter renovations in The Netherlands.

projects.title: A Feasibility Study on the Double Stage Flash Evaporation in a Low Temperature Thermal Desalination Process using Ocean Thermal Gradient
projects.description: A two stage flash evaporation process is designed for a Low Temperature Thermal Desalination (LTTD) plant whose capacity is twice the current plants available in Kavaratti, Agatti, Androth an Minicoy islands. Simultaneously, a single stage plant for the same capacity with single pass is designed. The obtained design for both types of plants are compared with the respective outputs obtained from HTRI software and with each other to determine the feasibility of the two stage plant.

contributors.headline: Doctoral Candidate, Building Services Group at Technische Universiteit Eindhoven

projects.title: Renovating houses in The Netherlands to nearly zero energy standard: Important drivers of economic feasibility (Master Thesis)
projects.description: The European Union through its Roadmap 2050 has mandated nearly zero energy as the standard for all building stock. While newly built buildings will be of nearly zero energy standard by 31 December 2020 (public-owned buildings after 31 December 2018), new buildings form only 1% of the addition to the existing building stock which implies that to attain nearly zero energy standard for all building stock, large-scale renovations must be performed. However, the renovation to the nearly zero energy standard is not yet cost optimal. To improve the economic feasibility, it is important to find the parameters that have an impact on the cost-optimality of nearly zero energy renovations and the extent of their impact, the results of which can be used to drive the renovation to the nearly zero energy standard in an economically feasible manner. The primary objectives of this thesis are the identification of the most important parameters influencing the cost-benefit analysis of renovating houses in The Netherlands to nearly zero energy standard and the extent of influence of each parameter on the economic feasibility. Five key parameters had an impact on the NPV- energy price, energy consumption (presented as four separate sub-parameters: electricity and gas consumption both before and after renovation), renovation cost, project life cycle and discount rate. In absolute terms, gas consumption before renovation had the highest impact followed by, renovation cost, electricity consumption after renovation, discount rate, a shift of energy price to the low price scenario, life cycle of the project and electricity consumption before renovation. The gas consumption after renovation and the shift of energy price to the high prices scenario did not have a significant effect on the NPV.

projects.title: A Book Review on Robert Shiller’s “The Subprime Solution: How today’s global financial crisis happened and what to do about it”
projects.description: The aim of the project was to write a review of Robert Shiller's "The subprime solution". The arguments made were summarized and appraised. Further, the book's stand in comparison with the wide range of literature on the Great Financial Crisis (GFC) was critically examined.

projects.title: Sustainable Microgrid in the Faroe Islands
projects.description: The objective of this project is to model and simulate a sustainable microgrid that can supply electricity to 50 households with an average power demand of 22.61kW with peak demand rising up to 54.1kW. Faroe Islands was chosen as the location to mimc the cold climatic conditions given in the problem statement. Wind energy was chosen as the primary energy source while hydropower was chosen for the secondary energy source. Lithium Iron Phosphate batteries were chosen for storage. The microgrid was modeled using MATLAB and Simulink. The results are discussed in the report.

projects.title: Tidal Energy Netherlands- Analysis of the Innovation System
projects.description: Sustainable energy technologies are present in today’s energy market. However, their contribution to total energy produced is for now minimal. It is known that electricity can be created from ocean currents, but the technologies are still developing. Tidal power is an example that is developing rapidly in the Netherlands, but it is still a small niche in the sustainable energy market. This research identifies what the drivers and hurdles are that tidal power companies in the Netherlands facing with respect to the Dutch energy market.  A social technological overview of tidal energy in the Netherlands is derived and with that information, a Function of Innovation System analysis is executed. This is combined with a multi-level perspective analysis, which is used to identify different regimes within the tidal power sector. The preliminary results of the research show that three functions there are the key drivers for tidal power in the Netherlands. These are knowledge diffusion, guidance of the search and mobilization of resources. The barriers are the market formation and support from advocacy coalitions. The multi-level perspective analysis shows that the general driver on the development of tidal energy is the general opinion that the embedded fossil fuel energy should be replaced or significantly reduced. To overcome the barriers, it is important that a market is going to be created which will attract more entrepreneurs. This will in turn lead to an increase in the number of demonstrations thereby proliferating the knowledge acquired and increasing the support for the tidal energy sector in the Netherlands.

projects.title: Analysis of a thermal storage unit containing multiple phase change materials  dispersed with high conductivity particles
projects.description: This paper investigates numerically the combined effect of employing multiple phase change materials (PCMs) and dispersion of high conductivity particles on the thermal performance of an energy storage unit. The key parameters that govern the performance have been identified following a simple reduction of variables. Among the different parameters, melting temperature of the PCMs, latent heat and melting temperature difference between two consecutive PCMs (Tm) were found to have a significant influence on the performance. A case study considering a 3-PCM unit to study the effect of key parameters during melting has been presented. The results show that for the 3-PCM unit, the performance is better when the second and third PCMs have their latent heats larger than the first PCM. It has been recommended to have Tm1 > Tm2 for the 3-PCM unit in order achieve more melting.

projects.title: Crank-X Manual: Standard Operating Procedures
projects.description: The teams, activities and events of Crank-X, the annual national technical symposium organized by the Department of Mechanical Engineering (SSN College of Engineering), were studied in great detail. Quality Statements and Objectives were framed for the symposium and Standard Operating Procedures were developed for the same and compiled into a manual and made available for the forthcoming batches to successfully organize the symposium.

projects.title: Numerical and Experimental Studies on a Multiple Phase Change Material (PCM) Latent Heat Thermal Storage (LHTS) unit
projects.description:
A latent heat thermal storage system consisting of a shell and tube arrangement with shell side filled with phase change material (PCM) and tube side carrying a heat transfer fluid (HTF) has been studied both numerically and experimentally considering the melting of the PCM. 

In the numerical model, a quasi steady state approach has been followed to arrive at the system of governing equations. The equations were solved adopting an alternate iteration between the temperature and thermal resistance. The thermal performance of the system was investigated for four different cases viz. (i) Shell side filled with single PCM without interspersed high conductivity particles, (ii) single PCM with high conductivity particles, (iii) shell side containing multiple (three) PCM without dispersed particles and (iv) shell side containing multiple (three) PCM with dispersed particles. A comparison between the four cases was made investigating their individual and combined influence on the performance of the unit for a set of input parameters especially the Biot number (Bi) and Stefan number (Ste). The results obtained showed that the performance of the multiple PCM with dispersed high conductivity particles was appreciable compared to the single PCM with or without dispersed high conductivity particles.

In the experiment, the entire shell and tube heat exchanger setup was broken down into three canisters for the convenience of adding or subtracting any PCM of interest. The temperature of the PCMs at set points and  the temperature of the HTF at the entry and exit of each canister were measured. The experiment was carried out for a total of 150 minutes and the temperature of the PCMs and HTF were noted down, initially at an interval of 3 minutes for 30 minutes and later at an interval of 5 minutes. A plot of the HTF temperature at various times showed that the system approached steady state. A comparison of the PCM temperatures at the various points showed congruency in melting.

projects.title: Design and Fabrication of Solar Parabolic Dish Collector for the distillation of water
projects.description: The scope of this project is to qualitatively compare the performance of satellite dishes as solar collectors when covered by different reflecting materials namely waste CDs, aluminum foil and polished plane mirrors and tap solar energy it for distillation of water. A parabolic satellite dish serves the purpose of a solar collector and polished mirrors adhered to the surface of the satellite dish are used to reflect the solar energy. A black body containing water is kept approximately at the focal point of the satellite dish. The water gets heated depending on the intensity of solar energy it takes. Subsequently the water is distilled and is collected elsewhere. Applications include converting brackish water in to clean water and heating of industrial oils.

projects.title: A Comparative Study On The Performance of a Latent Heat Thermal Storage Unit with Multiple PCM and Dispersed High Conductivity Particles in PCM- A Quasi Steady Approach
projects.description: A Latent Heat Thermal Storage System consisting of a shell and tube arrangement with shell side filled with Phase Change Material (PCM) and tube side carrying a Heat Transfer Fluid (HTF) has been studied numerically considering the melting of the PCM. A quasi steady state approach has been followed to arrive at the system of governing equations. The equations were solved adopting an alternate iteration between the temperature and thermal resistance. The thermal performance of the system was investigated for three different cases viz. (i) Shell side filled with single PCM with no particles (ii) PCM with particles and (iii)shell side containing multiple PCM with didpersed particles. A comparison between the three cases was made investigating their individual and combined influence on the performance of the unit for a set of input parameters especially the Biot number and Stefan number. The results obtained showed that the performance of the multiple PCM with dispersed high conductivity particles was appreciable compared to the single PCM with or without dispersed high conductivity particles.
